seg.seg: ... (if) he comes to the land (of Madhyadeśa); everywhere by the thousands,
… in every land (of Madhyadeśa) he comes to, in each of them (the beings honour him) by thousands. (cf 103)
... also when he left, people by the hundreds (part with) their parents
... they go. (Because of his) powerful and energetic kindness (shown) in innumerable great eons,
... whichever forest he may reach, there, (goaded) by the prong of (his) kindness, the wild beasts, (beginning with the) elephants,
whichever forest he may come to, there … (cf 103)
... pay homage to the noble Metrak. || In the Maitär [tune] || With lotus flowers in their trunks, elephants
... they performed respectfully the (rightward) circumambulation for him; lions and tigresses fell down on their bellies, full of joy; the soles of his feet
... we indeed are ... toward all good ones; by the killing of miserable animals we keep ourselves alive; of all beings
... to all we (are) instigators of fear. 2. We confess our sin - henceforth we will do no evil. (Like) other (animals)
We confess our sin[s]; we will do no more evil. (cf 103)

p.note: This fragment contains part of the second act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami II, 7b17-8b23. See also 195-6.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 104.
Cf. MaitrHami 2, 7 b17ff., and the last line of this leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 2, 8 b21-23 (for the Uy. references, cf. 18).
äñcaṃ: this pronominal form is miswritten as äñcä; see MaitrHami 2, 7 b27.
ewraṃ: the hapax legomenon TA ewar* (or ewär*) seems to mean ‘wild, ferocious’, cf. MaitrHami 2, 7 b28.
maitraṃ: three stanzas of 4 x 12 (5/7) syllables.

/// [t]w(a)nt[aṃ] is to be completed as (āpat) twantaṃ; the same collocation recurs in : b1 and : a6, and refers to the circumambulation rite, turning the right side towards a person or object (pradakṣiṇā); see MaitrHami 2, 8 a2-3.
For the beginning of the third strophe in this line, cf. MaitrHami 2, 8 a16ff.
maśkaṃ: this form seems to be regular for expected mar śkaṃ (); there is no need to correct to mar śkaṃ, pace 104.

śonaṃ: this is a locative singular, and is to be connected with the locative plural śonäṃtwaṃ, which occurs in : a7; according to the present context, śoṃ* would mean ‘bad form of existence’, cf. MaitrHami 2, 8 a28 (see also 172).
āṣträṃ: Here ends the first pāda of a stanza of the pattern 4 x 14 (7/7) syllables.
For the beginning of the second strophe in this line, cf. MaitrHami 2, 8 b11ff.
klumpäryaṃ: a stanza of 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables.

a4. äñcaṃ: this pronominal form is miswritten as äñcä; see MaitrHami 2, 7 b27.

a6. /// [t]w(a)nt[aṃ] is to be completed as (āpat) twantaṃ; the same collocation recurs in [[YQ II.2]]: b1 and [[A 24]]: a6, and refers to the circumambulation rite, turning the right side towards a person or object (pradakṣiṇā); see MaitrHami 2, 8 a2-3.

b2. maśkaṃ: this form seems to be regular for expected mar śkaṃ ([[Thomas 1963]]); there is no need to correct to mar śkaṃ, pace [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 104.
